commit_message:
Add actions for osd reweight and osd crush reweight

This commit adds the reweight, crush reweight,
and reweight-by-utilization actions to the ceph
mon charm. Additionally, unit_tests for these
actions has been implemented as well.

Change-Id: Id9c12f9f934bf39f827455b5d3be8dc560fd4523
Closes-Bug: #1675387
func-test-pr: https://github.com/openstack-charmers/zaza-openstack-tests/pull/253
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-ceph-mon refs/changes/19/665719/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: reweight.py

commit_message:
Regenerate example certificates using sha256 digest algorithm

Existing ones use sha1 which some openssl distributions refuse to verify
due to being obsolete and not FIPS compliant, leading to failing unit
tests.

Regenerating them using sha256 as the digest algorithm allows unit tests
to pass again.

Closes-Bug: #1981451
Change-Id: Ic34019e9c9742dafa67748e0c16b768893269339

commit_message:
[OVN] Sync QoS policies

The tool "neutron-ovn-db-sync-util" now syncs the Neutron QoS policies
with the OVN NB database. The tools reads the port and the floaiting IP
QoS policies and creates the corresponding OVN QoS rules.

The ovsdbapp library is bumped to version 1.15.0. This version updates
the "QoSAddCommand" to allow register updates. If the OVN NB QoS
register to be created is present in the DB and all parameters match,
no transaction is commited to the DB.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/ovsdbapp/+/822138
Closes-Bug: #1947334

Conflicts:
    lower-constraints.txt
    neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_driver/ovsdb/extensions/qos.py
    neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_driver/ovsdb/ovn_client.py
    neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_driver/ovsdb/ovn_db_sync.py
    neutron/tests/unit/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_driver/ovsdb/extensions/test_qos.py
    requirements.txt

Change-Id: Ib597b62017b56b41009dd4d7359e169f424272b0
(cherry picked from commit cde5657a504f6658cb1c9c98235c120030f86130)
(cherry picked from commit a51f243016c884bf9a8ed3fc4792a5227b750ed6)

commit_message:
[wip] Build a dib reference image

Making dib able to build everything of interest requires a bit of
external setup, and we only really validate it in one environment.
Traditionally this has been the same environment as nodepool-builder,
since that's what dib runs under in production.

To avoid having to duplicate fixes and avoid version skew, we've
avoided making a dib reference container that just contains dib.
However, there is some interest in moving image builds to be trigger
directly by Zuul jobs rather than nodepool-builder.  In that case, we
would want to run dib from it's own validated environment.  This
builds a container image the same as the nodepool-builder Debian
bullsye environment, incorporating the various bits from the nodepool
container seutp.

Change-Id: Ief1aae0b7f4215f0e77cfe49d2ac10cc9989d0fc

subject: Set sensible nf_conntrack_max value in amphora
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-06-24 08:27:02.000000000', 'files': ['octavia/amphorae/backends/agent/api_server/templates/amphora-netns.systemd.j2', 'releasenotes/notes/fix-nf-conntrack-max-value-in-amp-0e16eb50b42e7b58.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/octavia/commit/e367cd09478811113d225b6f59a11df5f31c827a', 'message': 'Set sensible nf_conntrack_max value in amphora

This sets the values of nf_conntrack_max and nf_conntrack_expect_max to
sensible values. Previously, the default values set by the kernel were
used, which limited net.netfilter.nf_conntrack_max to 32768. On the
other hand, Octavia sets nf_conntrack_buckets to 125000. A value of
nf_conntrack_max lower than half of that makes no sense.

The new values are calculated using the formula for the default value
in the kernel [1]:

nf_conntrack_max = nf_conntrack_buckets
nf_conntrack_expect_max = nf_conntrack_buckets / 256

[1]: https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/networking/nf_conntrack-sysctl.rst

commit_message:
Set sensible nf_conntrack_max value in amphora

This sets the values of nf_conntrack_max and nf_conntrack_expect_max to
sensible values. Previously, the default values set by the kernel were
used, which limited net.netfilter.nf_conntrack_max to 32768. On the
other hand, Octavia sets nf_conntrack_buckets to 125000. A value of
nf_conntrack_max lower than half of that makes no sense.

The new values are calculated using the formula for the default value
in the kernel [1]:

nf_conntrack_max = nf_conntrack_buckets
nf_conntrack_expect_max = nf_conntrack_buckets / 256

[1]: https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/networking/nf_conntrack-sysctl.rst

Story: 2010050
Task: 45460
Change-Id: Id1dd029995d41e6913a07eeb120c889d71d583eb
(cherry picked from commit 3d3e38afe9f0186f45e9800090afecc3aa434846)
(cherry picked from commit 78603681cce95048b76e2fcfabcdb0b5baf58c51)
(cherry picked from commit 33eaff55fc59c711e9a74dd94f55d84a54f09f56)
(cherry picked from commit d0adca9a34b5d2f36b821478d4e505f6592f222a)
(cherry picked from commit 4ea8953a698205764fcbc9617f441fd32f6a5ce2)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/octavia refs/changes/43/847543/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- upgrade: - | The fix that updates the Netfilter Conntrack Sysfs variables requires rebuilding the amphora image in order to be effective. fixes: - | Netfilter Conntrack Sysfs variables net.netfilter.nf_conntrack_max and nf_conntrack_expect_max get set to sensible values on the amphora now. Previously, kernel default values were used which were much too low for the configured net.netfilter.nf_conntrack_buckets value. As a result packets could get dropped because the conntrack table got filled too quickly. Note that this affects only UDP and SCTP protocol listeners. Connection tracking is disabled for TCP-based connections on the amphora including HTTP(S).

commit_message:
Set minimal tempest version to 27.0.0

As tempest.scenario.manager was announced stable interface in Tempest
27.0.0[1] it can be now reused in plugins.

Some methods replaced in scenario-manager-cleanup effort won't work
with tempest version lower than 27.0.0 therefore minimal tempest
version must be updated in tempest plugins

Etherpad concerning this effort:
https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/tempest-scenario-manager-cleanup

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/tempest/v27.0.0.html#release-notes-27-0-0

Change-Id: I422435abd4fb34fbba187deb0d96ef314767ff19

commit_message:
Remove create_volume & create_volume_type methods

As tempest.scenario.manager was announced stable interface in Tempest 27.0.0[1] it can be now reused in plugins.

Replaced methods:
	* create_volume
	* create_volume_type

Etherpad concerning this effort:
https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/tempest-scenario-manager-cleanup

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/tempest/v27.0.0.html#release-notes-27-0-0

Change-Id: I183a0f8190bf7f336370732d8d08d1bb28ad2835
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican-tempest-plugin refs/changes/46/833546/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: def create_volume(self, size=None, name=None, snapshot_id=None, imageRef=None, volume_type=None): if size is None: size = CONF.volume.volume_size if imageRef: image = self.compute_images_client.show_image(imageRef)['image'] min_disk = image.get('minDisk') size = max(size, min_disk) if name is None: name = data_utils.rand_name(self.__class__.__name__ + "-volume") kwargs = {'display_name': name, 'snapshot_id': snapshot_id, 'imageRef': imageRef, 'volume_type': volume_type, 'size': size} if CONF.compute.compute_volume_common_az: kwargs.setdefault('availability_zone', CONF.compute.compute_volume_common_az) volume = self.volumes_client.create_volume(**kwargs)['volume'] self.addCleanup(self.volumes_client.wait_for_resource_deletion, volume['id']) self.addCleanup(test_utils.call_and_ignore_notfound_exc, self.volumes_client.delete_volume, volume['id']) # NOTE(e0ne): Cinder API v2 uses name instead of display_name if 'display_name' in volume: self.assertEqual(name, volume['display_name']) else: self.assertEqual(name, volume['name']) waiters.wait_for_volume_resource_status(self.volumes_client, volume['id'], 'available') # The volume retrieved on creation has a non-up-to-date status. # Retrieval after it becomes active ensures correct details. volume = self.volumes_client.show_volume(volume['id'])['volume'] return volume def create_volume_type(self, client=None, name=None, backend_name=None): if not client: client = self.admin_volume_types_client if not name: class_name = self.__class__.__name__ name = data_utils.rand_name(class_name + '-volume-type') randomized_name = data_utils.rand_name('scenario-type-' + name) LOG.debug("Creating a volume type: %s on backend %s", randomized_name, backend_name) extra_specs = {} if backend_name: extra_specs = {"volume_backend_name": backend_name} body = client.create_volume_type(name=randomized_name, extra_specs=extra_specs) volume_type = body['volume_type'] self.assertIn('id', volume_type) self.addCleanup(client.delete_volume_type, volume_type['id']) return volume_type

commit_message:
Remove create_timestamp & get_timestamp methods

As tempest.scenario.manager was announced stable interface in Tempest 27.0.0[1] it can be now reused in plugins.

Replaced methods:
	* create_timestamp
	* get_timestamp

deleted_lines: def create_timestamp(self, ip_address, dev_name=None, mount_path='/mnt', private_key=None, server=None): ssh_client = self.get_remote_client(ip_address, private_key=private_key, server=server) if dev_name is not None: ssh_client.make_fs(dev_name) ssh_client.exec_command('sudo mount /dev/%s %s' % (dev_name, mount_path)) cmd_timestamp = 'sudo sh -c "date > %s/timestamp; sync"' % mount_path ssh_client.exec_command(cmd_timestamp) timestamp = ssh_client.exec_command('sudo cat %s/timestamp' % mount_path) if dev_name is not None: ssh_client.exec_command('sudo umount %s' % mount_path) return timestamp def get_timestamp(self, ip_address, dev_name=None, mount_path='/mnt', private_key=None, server=None): ssh_client = self.get_remote_client(ip_address, private_key=private_key, server=server) if dev_name is not None: ssh_client.mount(dev_name, mount_path) timestamp = ssh_client.exec_command('sudo cat %s/timestamp' % mount_path) if dev_name is not None: ssh_client.exec_command('sudo umount %s' % mount_path) return timestamp

commit_message:
Remove create_server and rebuild_server methods

As tempest.scenario.manager was announced stable interface in Tempest 27.0.0[1] it can be now reused in plugins.

Replaced methods:
	* create_server
	* rebuild_server

Etherpad concerning this effort:
https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/tempest-scenario-manager-cleanup

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/tempest/v27.0.0.html#release-notes-27-0-0

Change-Id: I3f9209fef4da9cc85d78060da0bad61682ff6b73
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican-tempest-plugin refs/changes/21/830121/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: from tempest.common import compute def create_server(self, name=None, image_id=None, flavor=None, validatable=False, wait_until='ACTIVE', clients=None, **kwargs): """Wrapper utility that returns a test server. This wrapper utility calls the common create test server and returns a test server. The purpose of this wrapper is to minimize the impact on the code of the tests already using this function. """ # NOTE(jlanoux): As a first step, ssh checks in the scenario # tests need to be run regardless of the run_validation and # validatable parameters and thus until the ssh validation job # becomes voting in CI. The test resources management and IP # association are taken care of in the scenario tests. # Therefore, the validatable parameter is set to false in all # those tests. In this way create_server just return a standard # server and the scenario tests always perform ssh checks. # Needed for the cross_tenant_traffic test: if clients is None: clients = self.os_primary if name is None: name = data_utils.rand_name(self.__class__.__name__ + "-server") vnic_type = CONF.network.port_vnic_type # If vnic_type is configured create port for # every network if vnic_type: ports = [] create_port_body = {'binding:vnic_type': vnic_type, 'namestart': 'port-smoke'} if kwargs: # Convert security group names to security group ids # to pass to create_port if 'security_groups' in kwargs: security_groups = \ clients.security_groups_client.list_security_groups( ).get('security_groups') sec_dict = dict([(s['name'], s['id']) for s in security_groups]) sec_groups_names = [s['name'] for s in kwargs.pop( 'security_groups')] security_groups_ids = [sec_dict[s] for s in sec_groups_names] if security_groups_ids: create_port_body[ 'security_groups'] = security_groups_ids networks = kwargs.pop('networks', []) else: networks = [] # If there are no networks passed to us we look up # for the project's private networks and create a port. # The same behaviour as we would expect when passing # the call to the clients with no networks if not networks: networks = clients.networks_client.list_networks( **{'router:external': False, 'fields': 'id'})['networks'] # It's net['uuid'] if networks come from kwargs # and net['id'] if they come from # clients.networks_client.list_networks for net in networks: net_id = net.get('uuid', net.get('id')) if 'port' not in net: port = self.create_port(network_id=net_id, client=clients.ports_client, **create_port_body) ports.append({'port': port['id']}) else: ports.append({'port': net['port']}) if ports: kwargs['networks'] = ports self.ports = ports tenant_network = self.get_tenant_network() body, servers = compute.create_test_server( clients, tenant_network=tenant_network, wait_until=wait_until, name=name, flavor=flavor, image_id=image_id, **kwargs) self.addCleanup(waiters.wait_for_server_termination, clients.servers_client, body['id']) self.addCleanup(test_utils.call_and_ignore_notfound_exc, clients.servers_client.delete_server, body['id']) server = clients.servers_client.show_server(body['id'])['server'] return server def rebuild_server(self, server_id, image=None, preserve_ephemeral=False, wait=True, rebuild_kwargs=None): if image is None: image = CONF.compute.image_ref rebuild_kwargs = rebuild_kwargs or {} LOG.debug("Rebuilding server (id: %s, image: %s, preserve eph: %s)", server_id, image, preserve_ephemeral) self.servers_client.rebuild_server( server_id=server_id, image_ref=image, preserve_ephemeral=preserve_ephemeral, **rebuild_kwargs) if wait: waiters.wait_for_server_status(self.servers_client, server_id, 'ACTIVE')

commit_message:
Remove handling of 'u' prefix

The prefix is no longer printed in Python 3.

In python 2
>>> print({u'foo': u'baa'})
{u'foo': u'baa'}
>>> print([u'foo', 'baa'])
[u'foo', 'baa']

In python 3
>>> print({u'foo': u'baa'})
{'foo': 'baa'}
>>> print([u'foo', 'baa'])
['foo', 'baa']

Change-Id: I30391cec53e425ee8cd0f94b31eb564098b47cb8

commit_message:
Disable setup.py auto discovery

Tripleo-ci jobs are broken after latest release of setuptools 61.0
because of breaking changes which are not backwork compatible,
details in related bug and [1].

[1] https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/issues/3197

Related-Bug: #1966382
Change-Id: Id60e8bc882f6c7944f89333fb539f6800ef43725

commit_message:
Add support for custom policies into the CLI

This is to ensure that we do not enforce "Server side" knowledge
 into the Client side library.

The policies available on the server of Nova API is only known by
 Nova and not by the client side librairies.  If the nova API
 developers decide to add other policies later down the train,
 this will enable them.  It also enable customers who implements
 their own policies on their Openstack instances.

There has been many upgrade to the policies and scheduler in the
recent years, a chunk of them to enable custom policies to be
registered by other librairies on the server-side.

Ref.
https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2008975
https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2008999
Change-Id: Ib6a6ddf0fa3ef39f2073bbc6ec2c740ae5dea2c9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/73/797373/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.create_and_assert_server_group_creation(name1, 'affinity') self.create_and_assert_server_group_creation(name2, 'anti-affinity') self.create_and_assert_server_group_creation(name2, 'custom-policy') def create_and_assert_server_group_creation(self, name, policy): json.loads(self.openstack( 'server group create -f json ' + '--policy ' + policy + ' ' + name )) self.addCleanup(self.openstack, 'server group delete ' + name) cmd_output = json.loads(self.openstack( 'server group show -f json ' + name)) self.assertEqual( name, cmd_output['name'] ) self.assertEqual( [policy], cmd_output['policies'] )
deleted_lines: cmd_output = json.loads(self.openstack( 'server group create -f json ' + '--policy affinity ' + name1 )) self.addCleanup(self.openstack, 'server group delete ' + name1) cmd_output = json.loads(self.openstack( 'server group show -f json ' + name1)) self.assertEqual( name1, cmd_output['name'] ) self.assertEqual( ['affinity'], cmd_output['policies'] ) cmd_output = json.loads(self.openstack( 'server group create -f json ' + '--policy anti-affinity ' + name2 )) self.addCleanup(self.openstack, 'server group delete ' + name2) cmd_output = json.loads(self.openstack( 'server group show -f json ' + name2)) self.assertEqual( name2, cmd_output['name'] ) self.assertEqual( ['anti-affinity'], cmd_output['policies'] )

commit_message:
Add support for custom policies into the CLI

This is to ensure that we do not enforce "Server side" knowledge
 into the Client side library.

The policies available on the server of Nova API is only known by
 Nova and not by the client side librairies.  If the nova API
 developers decide to add other policies later down the train,
 this will enable them.  It also enable customers who implements
 their own policies on their Openstack instances.

There has been many upgrade to the policies and scheduler in the
recent years, a chunk of them to enable custom policies to be
registered by other librairies on the server-side.

Ref.
https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2008975
https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2008999
Change-Id: Ib6a6ddf0fa3ef39f2073bbc6ec2c740ae5dea2c9

commit_message:
chunkeddriver: use iterative json encoding

When dumping the json file, we were using `json.dumps` that
essentially duplicates the memory usage by joining the chunks of the
string.

This patch instead uses `json.dump` with a custom encoder to encode in
utf-8 each chunk, so they can be written separately instead of having
to hold the whole encoded string in memory.

Closes-Bug: #1965799
Change-Id: Ia9214066db5baea50efb1e55f71b54e75e259cc5
Signed-off-by: David Caro <me@dcaro.es>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/27/834527/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Json encoder to avoid duplicating the whole json string in memory class JSONUTF8Encoder(json.JSONEncoder): def iterencode(self, *args, **kwargs): for chunk in super().iterencode(*args, **kwargs): yield chunk.encode("utf-8") with self._get_object_writer(container, filename) as writer: # this allows json-encoding in an iterative way instead of storing # the whole string in memory json.dump(obj=sha256file, fp=writer, sort_keys=True, indent=2, ensure_ascii=False, cls=JSONUTF8Encoder)
deleted_lines: sha256file_json = json.dumps(sha256file, sort_keys=True, indent=2) sha256file_json = sha256file_json.encode('utf-8') with self._get_object_writer(container, filename) as writer: writer.write(sha256file_json)

commit_message:
Alternate approach - Making sure the rdo check jobs use quay.rdoproj as well

This patch switches registry namespace to tripleowallabycentos8 based on whether cloudenv is vexxhost

Test proj: https://review.rdoproject.org/r/c/testproject/+/43953

subject: NVMe-oF: Fix encryption
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-03-31 17:59:07.000000000', 'files': ['os_brick/tests/initiator/connectors/test_nvmeof.py', 'os_brick/privileged/rootwrap.py', 'os_brick/initiator/connectors/nvmeof.py', 'os_brick/tests/privileged/test_rootwrap.py', 'releasenotes/notes/nvmeof-encryption-a4db72f0ab8563ab.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/os-brick/commit/206dc8ef4cd051af9dc490d170833aad6c5cd9b4', 'message': "NVMe-oF: Fix encryption

Only LUKS v1 encrypted volumes will work as expected, and that's because
nova doesn't use the os-brick decryptors but uses libvirt directly.

The problem with non LUKS v1 encrypted volumes is that the connector is
not returning a symlink like os-brick and nova expects, so when creating
the device mapper and doing the symlink we kind of destroy the actual
device (i.e., /dev/nvme0n1) and when we disconnect the volume the Linux
nvme driver will not remove the device.

So we'll have a broken device under /dev, and when we try to attach the
next nvmeof device it will not be able to replace the broken device we
left behind (doesn't matter if it's the same volume or a different one).

From that point onwards we'll have troubles attaching nvme devices.

This patch changes the nvmeof connector to return symlinks when doing an
encrypted connection as expected by the rest of the flow (just like we
do in iSCSI and other connectors).

Instead of using a symlink created by udev during the creation of the
device we instead create our own symlink that reflects what the original
device name was.  This is necessary for the disconnect, for things like
flushing the right device.

Closes-Bug: #1964379
Change-Id: Idddd3131ecf883cab01954f612a2a7e82039d102
"}]
commit_message:
NVMe-oF: Fix encryption

Only LUKS v1 encrypted volumes will work as expected, and that's because
nova doesn't use the os-brick decryptors but uses libvirt directly.

The problem with non LUKS v1 encrypted volumes is that the connector is
not returning a symlink like os-brick and nova expects, so when creating
the device mapper and doing the symlink we kind of destroy the actual
device (i.e., /dev/nvme0n1) and when we disconnect the volume the Linux
nvme driver will not remove the device.

So we'll have a broken device under /dev, and when we try to attach the
next nvmeof device it will not be able to replace the broken device we
left behind (doesn't matter if it's the same volume or a different one).

From that point onwards we'll have troubles attaching nvme devices.

This patch changes the nvmeof connector to return symlinks when doing an
encrypted connection as expected by the rest of the flow (just like we
do in iSCSI and other connectors).

Instead of using a symlink created by udev during the creation of the
device we instead create our own symlink that reflects what the original
device name was.  This is necessary for the disconnect, for things like
flushing the right device.

Closes-Bug: #1964379
Change-Id: Idddd3131ecf883cab01954f612a2a7e82039d102
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-brick refs/changes/61/836061/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- fixes: - | NVMe-oF connector `bug #1964379 <https://bugs.launchpad.net/os-brick/+bug/1964379>`_: Fixed using non LUKS v1 encrypted volumes, as once of such volumes is disconnected from a host all successive NVMe-oF attachments would fail.

commit_message:
Fix duplicate object error messages

Fixed an issue where creation of duplicate listeners or members may have
not returned the correct error message to users.
The API would traceback with AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'to_dict'

Made adjustments to patch for Python 2 compatibility in Train.

 Conflicts:
	octavia/api/v2/controllers/member.py
	octavia/api/v2/controllers/listener.py

commit_message:
Limit docutils to <0.19

docutils 0.19 deprecated frontend.OptionParser and in a later release
it will be replaced with an argparse.ArgumentParser based solution.
Till it is ready to avoid failing unit tests
(DockerReadmeTestCase.test_mentioned_latest_version and
DocstringsTestCase.test_all_plugins_have_docstrings) and unblock gate
cap docutils to <0.19

Change-Id: I2d82daa0d6d06fba8b386ac6a80a97cda6bc1630
Related-Bug: #1981194

commit_message:
Suppress 2 warnings from Docutils

The following 2 warnings do not require any modification of our code, so
we can silently hide them and wait for new release of docutils:

- The frontend.OptionParser class will be replaced by a subclass of
  argparse.ArgumentParser in Docutils 0.21 or later.
- The frontend.Option class will be removed in Docutils 0.21 or later.

Also, this commit temporary disables all dsvm job. They require a fix
for list-resources ansible role, but it would be nice to do that in a
separate change.

Change-Id: I82e794c3d12222db9380701e6923b6e065b596ac
Closes-Bug: 1981194

commit_message:
Control rally-openstack installed version

At the moment we don't have control what version of rally-openstack
is being installed. So we are installing latest version available in
PyPi. However rally package version is defined in
rally-openstack constraints.

With this patch we add variables to be able to adjust source of
rally-openstack as well as pick version for installation.

Needed-By: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible/+/847272
Change-Id: I8100dfd3544c0530815fb877b44b960d404f635b

commit_message:
Modify run_once behavior of tripleo_free strategy

It's very difficult to ensure that tasks are written without
run_once, expecting that they would be run with tripleo_free.
As tripleo_free does not ensure that the tasks are successfully
executed with run_once, let's go back to original ansible free
strategy behavior of running it for all hosts.

Change-Id: I1c67885f553aee519466249ac056f75071014c24
Resolves: rhbz#2061393
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ansible refs/changes/48/849448/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if action and getattr(action, 'BYPASS_HOST_LOOP', False): raise AnsibleError('Cannot bypass host loop with ansible_free strategy') else: display.warning("Using run_once with the tripleo_free strategy is not currently supported. " "This task will still be executed for every host in the inventory list.")
deleted_lines: - Handles run_once to only invoke the task a single time for a given run. It should be noted that run_once does not ensure the task actually is successful but rather that it is only triggered once time for the host groups. If the task fails, the playbook will fail at the end of the play but there is no assurance that the task will actually complete successfully for a given playbook execution. Other tasks will continue on the other hosts. display.warning('tripleo_free run_once does not ensure a task ' 'is successful for a given playbook but rather ' 'it is only attempted to execute once.') if action and getattr(action, 'BYPASS_HOST_LOOP', False): raise AnsibleError('Cannot bypass host loop with strategy') else: if task._uuid in self._run_once_tasks: # If the task was previously executed, just drop it # by clearing the blocked host and telling the parent # function to continue. self._debug("Skipping run_once task {} on {}".format( task._uuid, host)) del self._blocked_hosts[host_name] raise TripleoFreeContinue() else: self._run_once_tasks.add(task._uuid)

commit_message:
Optimize _local_delete calls by compute unit tests

_fake_do_delete function from nova/tests/unit/compute/test_api.py is
called with reservations=None argument. This argument is no longer used
in _local_delete. Since_fake_do_delete function is not really used
because it only contains pass statement, we can replace it with no op
call implemented using lambda function.

Change-Id: Idf9686afeadc2d000c3bc255e809c914967a063f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/85/844285/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _fake_do_delete(context, instance, bdms, local=False):
deleted_lines: def _fake_do_delete(context, instance, bdms, reservations=None, local=False):

commit_message:
Catch an exception in power off procedure

In libvirt driver, an exception of libvirt error may be thrown
when calling shutdown method.

This exception is caught by nobody, then the following retry
logic and the destroy method will be missed, causing the power
off procedure failure.

Catch this exception (as the retry logic does) to make the
procedure go on.

Change-Id: Icf9b15207a7e13333cf5640a5bce0e1082ecf4ec
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/76/817176/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: try: guest.shutdown() except libvirt.libvirtError: LOG.debug("Ignoring libvirt exception from shutdown " "request.", instance=instance)
deleted_lines: guest.shutdown()

commit_message:
Update endpoint to new proxy layer

Update endpoint to new openstack sdk

Change-Id: Ibd647d0c2cd2f90310f381e56088e7e8e93f76fc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ansible-collections-openstack refs/changes/40/840640/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- - name: Create a service for test openstack.cloud.endpoint: cloud: "{{ cloud }}" service: test endpoint_interface: public url: http://controller:9292 region: RegionOne state: present register: endpoint_test - name: Ensure service was created assert: that: - endpoint_test.endpoint.id is defined - name: Ensure service have the proper endpoint assert: that: - endpoint_test.endpoint.url == "http://controller:9292" - name: Update endpoint url openstack.cloud.endpoint: cloud: "{{ cloud }}" service: test endpoint_interface: public url: http://controller:9393 region: RegionOne state: present register: endpoint_updated - name: Ensure endpoint was updated assert: that: - endpoint_updated.endpoint.url == "http://controller:9393" - name: Delete endpoint openstack.cloud.endpoint: cloud: "{{ cloud }}" service: test endpoint_interface: public url: http://controller:9393 region: RegionOne state: absent register: endpoint_deleted - name: Ensure endpoint was deleted assert: that: - endpoint_deleted.changed is True

subject: Allow customisation of stick-tables for each service.

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-07-04 17:49:59.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-haproxy_server/commit/0867deaa3cdc0c3bc70b9e1eba4bd3a8309519c8', 'message': 'Allow customisation of stick-tables for each service.

A new variable "haproxy_stick_table" is added which allows a custom

for all haproxy back-ends.

In addition, the variable service.haproxy_stick_table can be defined

commit_message:
Allow customisation of stick-tables for each service.

A new variable "haproxy_stick_table" is added which allows a custom
stick-table to be supplied that is used as the default stick-table
for all haproxy back-ends.

In addition, the variable service.haproxy_stick_table can be defined
for each service to allow a unique stick-table to be supplied for
a particular service.

The old default stick-table definition is removed as there was no
use case defined for it in this role before. An example is added
to defaults/main.yml to show how the custom stick-table can be used
to rate-limit requests that generate 4xx responses which commonly
occur during vulnerability scanning or credential stuffing attacks.
There are many other uses for stick-tables, consult the HAProxy
documentation for details.

Change-Id: I50daba08c10f071157d6450ea2fa97df448f99ec
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-haproxy_server refs/changes/57/848657/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # haproxy_stick_table: # - "stick-table type ipv6 size 256k expire 10s store http_err_rate(10s)" # - "http-request track-sc0 src" # - "http-request deny deny_status 429 if { sc_http_err_rate(0) gt 20 } !{ src 10.0.0.0/8 } !{ src 172.16.0.0/12 } !{ src 192.168.0.0 }"

subject: Control rally-openstack installed version
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-07-05 19:18:07.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_rally/commit/90ff831a27e040fd0e25e7cdf12c0619995e9832', 'message': "Control rally-openstack installed version

At the moment we don't have control what version of rally-openstack
is being installed. So we are installing latest version available in
PyPi. However rally package version is defined in
rally-openstack constraints.

With this patch we add variables to be able to adjust source of
rally-openstack as well as pick version for installation.

commit_message:
Control rally-openstack installed version

At the moment we don't have control what version of rally-openstack
is being installed. So we are installing latest version available in
PyPi. However rally package version is defined in
rally-openstack constraints.

With this patch we add variables to be able to adjust source of
rally-openstack as well as pick version for installation.

We set some jobs as non-voting to resolve circular dependency.

Change-Id: I8100dfd3544c0530815fb877b44b960d404f635b

added_lines: import time def create_test_server(self, *args, **kwargs): """Whitebox is able to completely fill its compute hosts because it runs with things like PCI devices and dedicated CPUs. Because of that we cannot wait for the class cleanup to run after the test *class* (which is what Tempest does by default), we need to run cleanup after every test *method* to make sure subsequent tests have enough resources. This wrapper does that. """ def _admin_delete_server(server_id): """The server may have been created by an admin client. Use the admin client to delete it. """ try: self.os_admin.servers_client.delete_server(server_id) waiters.wait_for_server_termination( self.os_admin.servers_client, server_id) time.sleep(20) except Exception: LOG.exception('Failed to delete server %s', server_id) server = super(BaseWhiteboxComputeTest, self).create_test_server( *args, **kwargs) self.addCleanup(_admin_delete_server, server['id']) return server

commit_message:
setup.cfg: Replace dashes with underscores

Setuptools v54.1.0 introduces a warning that the use of
dash-separated options in 'setup.cfg' will not be supported
in a future version [1].
Get ahead of the issue by replacing the dashes with underscores.
Without this, we see 'UserWarning' messages
like the following on new enough
versions of setuptools:

  UserWarning: Usage of dash-separated 'description-file' will not be
  supported in future versions. Please use the underscore name
  'description_file' instead

[1] https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/commit/a2e9ae4cb

Change-Id: I4664cf66cd68526a81bb19ecb86f09ff0753f977

commit_message:
NetApp SolidFire: Fix race condition in delete cgsnapshot

A race condition in SolidFire API may occur between
"ListGroupSnapshots" and "DeleteGroupSnapshot" when called
concurrently, throwing API error "xSnapshotIDDoesNotExist". This
issue will commonly happen when multiple calls to delete
consistency group Snapshot are made.

This patch adds a coordination lock to serialize calls
to delete Consistency groups Snapshot, preventing them from
failing.

Change-Id: I6237cf9043f608a5f78ce6ef8eb0ef0e45cf95d4
Closes-Bug: #1791594
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/64/773564/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from cinder import coordination @coordination.synchronized('{f_name}') # NOTE(sfernand): A race condition in SolidFire API may occur # between "ListGroupSnapshots" and "DeleteGroupSnapshot" if called # concurrently. Added a coordination lock to prevent failures on multiple # calls to delete Consistency Group Snapshot. # For more details see: https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1791594 @coordination.synchronized('{f_name}')

added_lines: from swift.common.ring.io import RingReader, RingWriter, repair def test_repair(self, tempd): # Recompressing means we can't read it; can't find the index with self.assertRaises(IOError): # But we offer a primitive repair that ops can run offline repair(tempf) reader = RingReader(tempf) self.assertEqual(['foo', 'swift/index'], list(reader.index)) with reader.open_section('foo') as section: self.assertEqual(section.read(), b'\xde\xad\xbe\xef' * 10240) # Even works with uncompressed rings! with open(tempf, 'wb') as writer: writer.write(uncompressed_bytes) with self.assertRaises(zlib.error): RingReader(tempf) repair(tempf) reader = RingReader(tempf) self.assertEqual(['foo', 'swift/index'], list(reader.index)) with reader.open_section('foo') as section: self.assertEqual(section.read(), b'\xde\xad\xbe\xef' * 10240)

subject: ubuntu: more exact match on squashfs file
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-07-11 05:14:53.000000000', 'files': ['diskimage_builder/elements/ubuntu/root.d/10-cache-ubuntu-tarball'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder/commit/78adf92dca94881cfd50d77f2f9905c3b6a0362e', 'message': 'ubuntu: more exact match on squashfs file

The functests are failing with

 sha256sum: bionic-server-cloudimg-amd64.squashfs.manifest: No such file or directory

I think what has happened here is that the SHA256 sums file being used
has got a new entry "bionic-server-cloudimg-amd64.squashfs.manifest"
which is showing up in a grep for
"bionic-server-cloudimg-amd64.squashfs".  sha256 then tries to also
check this hash, and has started failing.

To avoid this, add an EOL marker to the grep so it only matches the
exact filename.

Change-Id: Id5f134d772d56640990b5c7bf40739c21e2d8aa3
'}]
commit_message:
ubuntu: more exact match on squashfs file

The functests are failing with

 sha256sum: bionic-server-cloudimg-amd64.squashfs.manifest: No such file or directory

I think what has happened here is that the SHA256 sums file being used
has got a new entry "bionic-server-cloudimg-amd64.squashfs.manifest"
which is showing up in a grep for
"bionic-server-cloudimg-amd64.squashfs".  sha256 then tries to also
check this hash, and has started failing.

To avoid this, add an EOL marker to the grep so it only matches the
exact filename.

Change-Id: Id5f134d772d56640990b5c7bf40739c21e2d8aa3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/67/849267/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if ! grep "${BASE_IMAGE_FILE}$" $CACHED_SUMS | sha256sum --check - ; then grep "${BASE_IMAGE_FILE}$" $CACHED_SUMS | sha256sum --check -
deleted_lines: if ! grep "$BASE_IMAGE_FILE" $CACHED_SUMS | sha256sum --check - ; then grep "$BASE_IMAGE_FILE" $CACHED_SUMS | sha256sum --check -

commit_message:
Add acceptance tests for config management resources

Change-Id: I3516381afe6bae49a78ed9ab2c98b23a7cb6e258
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-cinder refs/changes/58/849158/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: require 'spec_helper_acceptance' describe 'basic cinder_config resource' do context 'default parameters' do it 'should work with no errors' do pp= <<-EOS Exec { logoutput => 'on_failure' } File <||> -> cinder_config <||> File <||> -> cinder_api_paste_ini <||> File <||> -> cinder_rootwrap_config <||> file { '/etc/cinder' : ensure => directory, } file { '/etc/cinder/cinder.conf' : ensure => file, } cinder_config { 'DEFAULT/thisshouldexist' : value => 'foo', } cinder_config { 'DEFAULT/thisshouldnotexist' : value => '<SERVICE DEFAULT>', } cinder_config { 'DEFAULT/thisshouldexist2' : value => '<SERVICE DEFAULT>', ensure_absent_val => 'toto', } cinder_config { 'DEFAULT/thisshouldnotexist2' : value => 'toto', ensure_absent_val => 'toto', } cinder_api_paste_ini { 'DEFAULT/thisshouldexist' : value => 'foo', } cinder_api_paste_ini { 'DEFAULT/thisshouldnotexist' : value => '<SERVICE DEFAULT>', } cinder_api_paste_ini { 'DEFAULT/thisshouldexist2' : value => '<SERVICE DEFAULT>', ensure_absent_val => 'toto', } cinder_api_paste_ini { 'DEFAULT/thisshouldnotexist2' : value => 'toto', ensure_absent_val => 'toto', } cinder_rootwrap_config { 'DEFAULT/thisshouldexist' : value => 'foo', } cinder_rootwrap_config { 'DEFAULT/thisshouldnotexist' : value => '<SERVICE DEFAULT>', } cinder_rootwrap_config { 'DEFAULT/thisshouldexist2' : value => '<SERVICE DEFAULT>', ensure_absent_val => 'toto', } cinder_rootwrap_config { 'DEFAULT/thisshouldnotexist2' : value => 'toto', ensure_absent_val => 'toto', } EOS # Run it twice and test for idempotency apply_manifest(pp, :catch_failures => true) apply_manifest(pp, :catch_changes => true) end describe file('/etc/cinder/cinder.conf') do it { is_expected.to exist } it { is_expected.to contain('thisshouldexist=foo') } it { is_expected.to contain('thisshouldexist2=<SERVICE DEFAULT>') } describe '#content' do subject { super().content } it { is_expected.to_not match /thisshouldnotexist/ } end end describe file('/etc/cinder/api-paste.ini') do it { is_expected.to exist } it { is_expected.to contain('thisshouldexist=foo') } it { is_expected.to contain('thisshouldexist2=<SERVICE DEFAULT>') } describe '#content' do subject { super().content } it { is_expected.to_not match /thisshouldnotexist/ } end end describe file('/etc/cinder/rootwrap.conf') do it { is_expected.to exist } it { is_expected.to contain('thisshouldexist=foo') } it { is_expected.to contain('thisshouldexist2=<SERVICE DEFAULT>') } describe '#content' do subject { super().content } it { is_expected.to_not match /thisshouldnotexist/ } end end end end

commit_message:
Switch provider to manage paste.ini file

... so that we users can use '<SERVICE DEFAULT>' similarly to
the resource types to manage the <service>.conf files.

Closes-Bug: #1981118
Change-Id: Ie967ffa9e2545d9089aaa4b255b13f479d296ff7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-cinder refs/changes/71/849171/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: :parent => Puppet::Type.type(:openstack_config).provider(:ini_setting)
deleted_lines: :parent => Puppet::Type.type(:ini_setting).provider(:ruby) def section resource[:name].split('/', 2).first end def setting resource[:name].split('/', 2).last end def separator '=' end # added for backwards compatibility with older versions of inifile def file_path self.class.file_path end

commit_message:
Add support for rootwrap.conf

Change-Id: Ib28c3f1a8b46c439a16874c5695f121bf63c3bb9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-glance refs/changes/61/849161/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: require 'puppet' require 'puppet/type/glance_rootwrap_config' describe 'Puppet::Type.type(:glance_rootwrap_config)' do before :each do @glance_rootwrap_config = Puppet::Type.type(:glance_rootwrap_config).new(:name => 'DEFAULT/foo', :value => 'bar') end it 'should require a name' do expect { Puppet::Type.type(:glance_rootwrap_config).new({}) }.to raise_error(Puppet::Error, 'Title or name must be provided') end it 'should not expect a name with whitespace' do expect { Puppet::Type.type(:glance_rootwrap_config).new(:name => 'f oo') }.to raise_error(Puppet::Error, /Parameter name failed/) end it 'should fail when there is no section' do expect { Puppet::Type.type(:glance_rootwrap_config).new(:name => 'foo') }.to raise_error(Puppet::Error, /Parameter name failed/) end it 'should not require a value when ensure is absent' do Puppet::Type.type(:glance_rootwrap_config).new(:name => 'DEFAULT/foo', :ensure => :absent) end it 'should accept a valid value' do @glance_rootwrap_config[:value] = 'bar' expect(@glance_rootwrap_config[:value]).to eq('bar') end it 'should not accept a value with whitespace' do @glance_rootwrap_config[:value] = 'b ar' expect(@glance_rootwrap_config[:value]).to eq('b ar') end it 'should accept valid ensure values' do @glance_rootwrap_config[:ensure] = :present expect(@glance_rootwrap_config[:ensure]).to eq(:present) @glance_rootwrap_config[:ensure] = :absent expect(@glance_rootwrap_config[:ensure]).to eq(:absent) end it 'should not accept invalid ensure values' do expect { @glance_rootwrap_config[:ensure] = :latest }.to raise_error(Puppet::Error, /Invalid value/) end it 'should autorequire the package that install the file' do catalog = Puppet::Resource::Catalog.new anchor = Puppet::Type.type(:anchor).new(:name => 'glance::install::end') catalog.add_resource anchor, @glance_rootwrap_config dependency = @glance_rootwrap_config.autorequire expect(dependency.size).to eq(1) expect(dependency[0].target).to eq(@glance_rootwrap_config) expect(dependency[0].source).to eq(anchor) end end

commit_message:
Configure the oslo.concurrency lock_path

A recent change in os-brick [1], which is used by cinder backends,
requires external file locks. This patch adds support for configuring
the lock path, with a default value that matches the corresponding
lock paths used by other services that use os-brick (namely cinder
and nova).

[1] I6f7f7d19540361204d4ae3ead2bd6dcddb8fcd68

Closes-Bug: #1980539
Change-Id: I5ea6766656f4227a1c514777c03bbf78d4ac59cd
(cherry picked from commit 6f61ecd9c5b030817d0255fd8fd485722f9556f4)
(cherry picked from commit ba4ada0c70b31277b8569b71d40692b17c2a632b)

added_lines: $lock_path = '/var/lib/glance/tmp' $lock_path = '/var/lock/glance'

commit_message:
Remove nova-network security groups methods

As tempest.scenario.manager was announced stable interface in Tempest 27.0.0[1] it can be now reused in plugins.

Replaced methods:
	* _create_security_group
	* _create_loginable_secgroup_rule

Etherpad concerning this effort:
https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/tempest-scenario-manager-cleanup

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/tempest/v27.0.0.html#release-notes-27-0-0

Change-Id: Idd6c9066cec143e358078babf1802dce60265114
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila-tempest-plugin refs/changes/19/834819/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: def _create_loginable_secgroup_rule(self, secgroup_id=None): _client = self.compute_security_groups_client _client_rules = self.compute_security_group_rules_client if secgroup_id is None: sgs = _client.list_security_groups()['security_groups'] for sg in sgs: if sg['name'] == 'default': secgroup_id = sg['id'] # These rules are intended to permit inbound ssh and icmp # traffic from all sources, so no group_id is provided. # Setting a group_id would only permit traffic from ports # belonging to the same security group. rulesets = [ { # ssh 'ip_protocol': 'tcp', 'from_port': 22, 'to_port': 22, 'cidr': '0.0.0.0/0', }, { # ping 'ip_protocol': 'icmp', 'from_port': -1, 'to_port': -1, 'cidr': '0.0.0.0/0', } ] rules = list() for ruleset in rulesets: sg_rule = _client_rules.create_security_group_rule( parent_group_id=secgroup_id, **ruleset)['security_group_rule'] rules.append(sg_rule) return rules def _create_security_group(self): # Create security group sg_name = data_utils.rand_name(self.__class__.__name__) sg_desc = sg_name + " description" secgroup = self.compute_security_groups_client.create_security_group( name=sg_name, description=sg_desc)['security_group'] self.assertEqual(secgroup['name'], sg_name) self.assertEqual(secgroup['description'], sg_desc) self.addCleanup( test_utils.call_and_ignore_notfound_exc, self.compute_security_groups_client.delete_security_group, secgroup['id']) # Add rules to the security group self._create_loginable_secgroup_rule(secgroup['id']) return secgroup

commit_message:
Debian/Ubuntu: Use tftpd-hpa instead of tftpd

The tftpd-hpa package possesses a number of bugfixes and enhancements
over the original tftpd package. Especially it supports the 'tsize'
which is required by PXE.

Change-Id: I41b95f80ed4d972a65f25541d2c5f4ae2df79d60
(cherry picked from commit 80307bece658a7bc6897cf5a57ca4eab3fa466cd)

commit_message:
Ubuntu: Use utf8mb3 charset in MySQL

... to fix the broken idempotency in litmus job. Current mysql/mariadb
in Ubuntu replaces utf8 with uft8mb3 automatically and this behavior
results in unexpected change in second run.

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/804365
Related-Bug: #1929073
Change-Id: I41a6fe11e8ab39a60b19299da18ee085a10dc202

commit_message:
Deprecate redundant DockerNovaMigrationSshdPort

Currently we have the following two parameters to control the tcp port
for ssh connection used by nova migration feature.

1) MigrationSshPort
This parameter determines the tcp port defined in ssh client
configuration and also the one allowed by firewall rule.

2) DockerNovaMigrationSshdPort
This parameter determines tcp port which sshd for nova migration
listens on.

This is very redundant, especially considering the fact that users
should update these two parameters consistently to change port number
from the default one.

This change deprecates the DockerNovaMigrationSshdPort parameter, so
that we can replace that by MigrationSshPort in a future release, and
provide only that single parameter.

Also, some constraints about port number has been added, to accept
a value within the valid range.

Change-Id: Ia80c8b8711cda4d6189051d75eb13967a44dc40d

commit_message:
upgrading subchart config only impacts subchart

This verifies that making a configuration change to one of Umbrella's
subcharts results in only the application (DaemonSet, Deployment or
StatefulSet) for that subchart being updated. No other subchart's
application should be updated.

This only validates subcharts from openstack-helm-infra.
Validating the remaining subcharts from openstack-helm will
be done in the future.

OpenStack Umbrella's default values for rabbitmq was configured
to use a host path. This is so rabbitmq retains its data
between StatefulSet changes. Otherwise components fail to authenticate
with rabbitmq after the rabbitmq pods have been recreated. The
OpenStack Umbrella Chart will use the `standard` storage class
by default since that's what is provisioned via minikube.

Change-Id: I8570e32e6ae03563037608d337f31066edf29755

commit_message:
Remove check_floating_ip_status & _associate_floating_ip methods

As tempest.scenario.manager was announced stable interface
in Tempest 27.0.0[1] it can be now reused in plugins.

Replaced methods:
	* _associate_floating_ip
	* check_floating_ip_status

Etherpad concerning this effort:
https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/tempest-scenario-manager-cleanup

The commit also bumps the minimal version of tempest in the
requirements to tempest>=27.0.0.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/tempest/v27.0.0.html#release-notes-27-0-0

Change-Id: Ie17c1d9349e98ce016801bf47c1cb9dba18b51f6

" "failed to reach status: {st}" .format(fp=floating_ip, cst=floating_ip['status'], st=status)) LOG.info("FloatingIP: {fp} is at status: {st}" .format(fp=floating_ip, st=status))

commit_message:
Fix quota list command for non-admin users

Due to a logic error the all-projects header was being set if no
explicit project was being specified.

Closes-Bug: 1980942
Change-Id: I3c492b4ffd1b75a42a6a152b1dea219e4986f411

subject: Ensure bootstrap packages are correctly installed
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-07-08 10:13:42.000000000', 'files': ['tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_bootstrap/tasks/packages.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ansible/commit/cca76e8dfec896a8a7eafc4a9414e9a695b1cb44', 'message': 'Ensure bootstrap packages are correctly installed

It may happen a package fails to properly install (especially for
openstack-selinux). Unfortunately, in such cases rpm will just output
some warning lost in the output, and will still exit with a success code
(0).

This patch allows to leverage the "--verify" option of RPM. If a package
spec file has a %verifyscript scriptlet, it will be called, and do
whatever is described in it.
In openstack-selinux case, it will ensure everything is actually
installed without issue[1].
If a package doesn't have the %verifyscript, rpm will just exit 0
without any error nor warning.

Note:
the failed_when condition allows to:
- protect against missing package (openvswitch)
- ensure we're actually failing on the %verifyscript
The second part is useful when we don't get the doc for package -
apparently, this is the case for python3-pyyaml, at least in CI
(molecule).

[1] https://review.rdoproject.org/r/c/openstack/openstack-selinux-distgit/+/43578

Change-Id: Iec1e79c9c1cbb6b7e5e7b768d425aab8270c1d89
(cherry picked from commit 2f29bfb7e01d94e42e5e6fcc9305f339d8d5efe4)
'}]
commit_message:
Ensure bootstrap packages are correctly installed

It may happen a package fails to properly install (especially for
openstack-selinux). Unfortunately, in such cases rpm will just output
some warning lost in the output, and will still exit with a success code
(0).

This patch allows to leverage the "--verify" option of RPM. If a package
spec file has a %verifyscript scriptlet, it will be called, and do
whatever is described in it.
In openstack-selinux case, it will ensure everything is actually
installed without issue[1].
If a package doesn't have the %verifyscript, rpm will just exit 0
without any error nor warning.

Note:
the failed_when condition allows to:
- protect against missing package (openvswitch)
- ensure we're actually failing on the %verifyscript
The second part is useful when we don't get the doc for package -
apparently, this is the case for python3-pyyaml, at least in CI
(molecule).

[1] https://review.rdoproject.org/r/c/openstack/openstack-selinux-distgit/+/43578

Change-Id: Iec1e79c9c1cbb6b7e5e7b768d425aab8270c1d89
(cherry picked from commit 2f29bfb7e01d94e42e5e6fcc9305f339d8d5efe4)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ansible refs/changes/95/848995/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: Ensure packages are actually well installed command: "rpm -V {{ tripleo_bootstrap_packages_bootstrap | join(' ') }}" register: rpm_verify_result failed_when: - "'%verify' in rpm_verify_result.stderr"

commit_message:
ibm_storage: Remove unused _get_os_type method

platform.dist() doesn't exist on Python 3.8+, so this
no longer works.  This method is not called by any
other code.

Change-Id: I97b000ad8eb2bf63aaa0bb110be6ca39b8359a94
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/80/844880/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: import platform @_trace_time def _get_os_type(self): """Gets a string representation of the current os""" dist = platform.dist() return "%s-%s-%s" % (dist[0], dist[1], platform.processor())

commit_message:
pylint: skip ManageResource Mixin

cinder.api.v3.resource_common_manage.ManageResource
is not automatically detected as a Mixin due to its
name, so manually list it here to skip no-member
checks.

added_lines: In Zed, we'll do the following: * The Cinder `Policy Personas and Permissions` document in the Zed * The only "system-\*" persona to be implemented in Zed is the "system-admin". unchanged from Yoga, though they will be explicitly "project-scoped" in Zed. There is a patch up addressing this: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/835525 * Various legacy policies were DEPRECATED in Xena. They must be removed early in Zed to get them out of the way, because we'll have new deprecations in Zed. * Once the policy matrix document has been revised and the deprecated policies have been removed, we'll be able to add a 'scope_types' field to each policy rule. * NOTE: there's a slight complication here in that I believe that the scope_types defined with a rule CANNOT be overriden by a policy file. So what we set for scope_types in Zed may need to be more broad than what we'll want in AA. For Zed, we will allow anyone with the 'admin' role to see the volumes statement for why it's being done this way.)``enforce_scope=True`` in the AA release. (The importance of this is thatWe will also plan to do Phase 2 [8]_ of the community goal during the Zed development cycle: * Implement the "project-manager" persona. This depends on Keystone implementing the 'manager' role and inserting it in the role hierarchy. The spec [4]_ for this has been merged, though it has not yet been implemented. There is a patch up for this, however: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/keystone/+/822601 * Implement recognition of the 'service' role. This has a Keystone dependency (creation of the 'service' role during Keystone bootstrap), but all we need on the cinder side is agreement that the role will be named 'service'. That's because any of the service actions should also be performable by a system administrator, so if there's no service role, services will continue to use admin credentials as they do currently. As mentioned above, by completing Phase 1 in Zed, we should also be in a positon to complete Phase 3 during the AA development cycle. master for the Zed policy changes described above... [4] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/keystone-specs/specs/keystone/yoga/default-manager-role.html
deleted_lines: In Yoga, we'll do the following: * The Cinder `Policy Personas and Permissions` document merged in Xena [4]_ contained forward-looking information about what would be done in Yoga. Unfortunately, this is no longer accurate. The stable/xena version of this document should be revised to describe *only* the Xena changes so that operators aren't misled about the direction the effort is taking. There is a patch up addressing this: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/818696 * The Cinder `Policy Personas and Permissions` document in the Yoga unchanged from Xena, though they will be explicitly "project-scoped" in Yoga.* Once the document has been revised, we'll be able to add a 'scope_types' field to each policy rule. For Yoga, we will allow anyone with the 'admin' role to see the volumes statement for why it's being done this way for Yoga.)``enforce_scope=True`` in the Z release. (The importance of this is thatWe will plan to do Phase 2 [8]_ of the community goal during the Z development cycle. See the community goal document for details. As mentioned above, by completing Phase 1 in Yoga, we should also be in a positon to complete Phase 3 during the Z development cycle. stable/xena branch. * Update the Cinder *Policy Personas and Permissions* document in the master for the Yoga policy changes described above.* Client changes to support system scope: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-cinderclient/+/776469.. [4] https://docs.openstack.org/cinder/xena/configuration/block-storage/policy-personas.html

subject: Move bandit requirements to tox.ini
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-06-27 15:03:39.000000000', 'files': ['test-requirements.txt', 'tox.ini'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/befa5b5be8cbe62c5bd5dff6f7744a10113dfdd4', 'message': 'Move bandit requirements to tox.ini

This makes bandit requirements work like our
pylint requirements.  (Neither are handled
in the typical way by openstack/requirements.)

This prevents needless installation of bandit

Change-Id: I513de53520a4531067cea4e7a225fb1ad2e9ba06
'}]
commit_message:
Move bandit requirements to tox.ini

This makes bandit requirements work like our
pylint requirements.  (Neither are handled
in the typical way by openstack/requirements.)

This prevents needless installation of bandit
for each unit test job run.

Change-Id: I513de53520a4531067cea4e7a225fb1ad2e9ba06
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/01/847801/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
upgrading an OSH subchart config only impacts subchart

This verifies that making a configuration change to one of Umbrella's
subcharts results in only the application (DaemonSet, Deployment or
StatefulSet) for that subchart being updated. No other subchart's
application should be updated.

This only validates subcharts from openstack-helm.
Validating the remaining subcharts from openstack-helm-infra has
been done in another commit.

Change-Id: I649dde64313dfaaa7440c86fd50c3882874bf122
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-helm refs/changes/58/848658/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
[WIP] Added lifecycle management isolation testing to OpenStack Umbrella
chart

    Gate scripts to test the changes submitted to OpenStack Umbrella chart. These scripts will upgrade umbrella chart with test cases (changes) to a sub-chart and ensures that this upgrade is not affecting other sub-charts.

Change-Id: I1412e07c88675aeb431b9e284df32f79e559d367

added_lines: # Andi Chandler <andi@gowling.com>, 2022. #zanata"POT-Creation-Date: 2022-05-18 22:20+0000\n""PO-Revision-Date: 2022-05-25 08:36+0000\n"msgid "10.1.0-11" msgstr "10.1.0-11" msgid "12.0.0-13" msgstr "12.0.0-13" msgid "13.0.0" msgstr "13.0.0" msgid "13.0.0-13" msgstr "13.0.0-13" msgid "14.0.0" msgstr "14.0.0" msgid "9.0.1-17" msgstr "9.0.1-17" "Fixed Story #2009247 - Fixed the response for POST /v1/secrets/{secret-id}/" "metadata so it matches the documented behavior." msgstr "" "Fixed Story #2009247 - Fixed the response for POST /v1/secrets/{secret-id}/" "metadata so it matches the documented behaviour." msgid "" "Fixed Story #2009672 - Fixed validator for Container Consumers to prevent " "500 errors." msgstr "" "Fixed Story #2009672 - Fixed validator for Container Consumers to prevent " "500 errors." msgid "" "Fixed Story #2009791: Users with the \"creator\" role on a project can now " "delete secrets owned by the project even if the user is different than the " "user that originally created the secret. Previous to this fix a user with " "the \"creator\" role was only allowed to delete a secret owned by the " "project if they were also the same user that originally created, which was " "inconsistent with the way that deletes are handled by other OpenStack " "projects that integrate with Barbican. This change does not affect private " "secrets (i.e. secrets with the \"project-access\" flag set to \"false\")." msgstr "" "Fixed Story #2009791: Users with the \"creator\" role on a project can now " "delete secrets owned by the project even if the user is different than the " "user that originally created the secret. Previous to this fix a user with " "the \"creator\" role was only allowed to delete a secret owned by the " "project if they were also the same user that originally created it, which " "was inconsistent with the way that deletes are handled by other OpenStack " "projects that integrate with Barbican. This change does not affect private " "secrets (i.e. secrets with the \"project-access\" flag set to \"false\")." msgid """Fixed Story 2009664 - Fixed the Consumer controller to be able to use the " "associated Container's ownership information in policy checks." msgstr "" "Fixed Story 2009664 - Fixed the Consumer controller to be able to use the " "associated Container's ownership information in policy checks." msgid ""msgid "" "Part of the fix for Story 2009664 required renaming the policy for Container " "Consumers from \"consumers:get\" to \"container_consumers:get\", \"consumers:" "post\" to \"container_consumers:post\", and \"consumers:delete\" to " "\"container_consumers:delete\". If you are using custom policies to " "override the default policies you will need to update them to use the new " "names." msgstr "" "Part of the fix for Story 2009664 required renaming the policy for Container " "Consumers from \"consumers:get\" to \"container_consumers:get\", \"consumers:" "post\" to \"container_consumers:post\", and \"consumers:delete\" to " "\"container_consumers:delete\". If you are using custom policies to " "override the default policies you will need to update them to use the new " "names." msgid "Yoga Series Release Notes" msgstr "Yoga Series Release Notes"

different types of blob/indexes.

All RingSerialization classes are based of the RingSerializeBase class
which provides a serialize and deserialize method. As well as the
index_name. When concrete RingSerialization classes are made, we
register them with the base class class method function decorator, to
build up a map of index_names to classes which allows us to easily walk
through the RingReader's index and serialize or deserialize the
requested section. Ie:

  @RingSerializeBase.register()
  class RingSerializeMetadata(RingSerializeBase):

It is also defining a constant:

  RING_SERIALIZATION_INDEXES = ('swift/metadata', 'swift/devs',
                                'swift/replica2part2dev')

Because we'd want a way for telling what particular indexes to load up
in the ring. This might seem like overkill in engineering, but this is a
stepping stone to allowing us to store the builder components in the ring.
And should help us reuse and tell what components we want in the builder
and the ring.

commit_message:
Add (de)serialize_v2 via RingSerialization classes

This patch also changes the way v2 serialization/deserialization works by
breaking it down into RingSerialization classes that handle dealing with
different types of blob/indexes.

All RingSerialization classes are based of the RingSerializeBase class
which provides a serialize and deserialize method, as well as the
index_name. When concrete RingSerialization classes are made, we
register them with the base class class method function decorator, to
build up a map of index_names to classes which allows us to easily walk
through the RingReader's index and serialize or deserialize the
requested section. Ie:

  @RingSerializeBase.register()
  class RingSerializeMetadata(RingSerializeBase):

It is also defining a constant:

  RING_SERIALIZATION_INDEXES = ('swift/metadata', 'swift/devs',
                                'swift/replica2part2dev')

Because we'd want a way for telling what particular indexes to load up
in the ring. This might seem like overkill in engineering, but this is a
stepping stone to allowing us to store the builder components in the ring.
And should help us reuse and tell what components we want in the builder
and the ring.

Change-Id: If086817d5f3d02e62d9c504373419225292e0651
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/23/834423/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from swift.common.ring.utils import tiers_for_dev, BYTES_TO_TYPE_CODE@contextlib.contextmanager def network_order_array(arr): if sys.byteorder == 'little': # Switch to network-order for serialization arr.byteswap() try: yield arr finally: if sys.byteorder == 'little': # Didn't make a copy; switch it back arr.byteswap() def read_network_order_array(type_code, data): arr = array.array(type_code, data) if sys.byteorder == 'little': arr.byteswap() return arr ring_dict['dev_id_bytes'] = 2 def deserialize_v2(cls, reader, metadata_only=False): """ Deserialize a v2 ring file into a dictionary with `devs`, `part_shift`, and `replica2part2dev_id` keys. If the optional kwarg `metadata_only` is True, then the `replica2part2dev_id` is not loaded and that key in the returned dictionary just has the value `[]`. :param file reader: An opened RingReader object. :param bool metadata_only: If True, only load `devs` and `part_shift` :returns: A dict containing `devs`, `part_shift`, and `replica2part2dev_id` """ # pull metadata out of the file with reader.open_section('swift/metadata') as r: ring_dict = json.load(r) ring_dict['replica2part2dev_id'] = [] ring_dict['devs'] = [] if metadata_only: # Note empty devs and replica2part2dev table return ring_dict # Now grab the devs with reader.open_section('swift/devs') as r: ring_dict['devs'] = json.load(r) # other interesting metadata partition_count = 1 << (32 - ring_dict['part_shift']) max_row_len = ring_dict['dev_id_bytes'] * partition_count type_code = BYTES_TO_TYPE_CODE[ring_dict['dev_id_bytes']] with reader.open_section('swift/replica2part2dev') as r: for row in iter(lambda: r.read(max_row_len), b''): ring_dict['replica2part2dev_id'].append( read_network_order_array(type_code, row)) return ring_dict @classmethod elif reader.version == 2: ring_data = cls.deserialize_v2( reader, metadata_only=metadata_only) writer.write_ring_version(1) def serialize_v2(self, writer): # Write out new-style serialization magic and version: writer.write_ring_version(2) ring = self.to_dict() # First let's write the metadata, as this is the first we pull out # in deserialize. metadata = {'part_shift': ring['part_shift'], 'dev_id_bytes': ring['dev_id_bytes']} if ring['version'] is not None: metadata['version'] = ring['version'] next_part_power = ring.get('next_part_power') if next_part_power is not None: metadata['next_part_power'] = next_part_power with writer.section('swift/metadata'): writer.write_json(metadata) # Next as the dev structure is getting rather large, let's right # it next as it's own blob. with writer.section('swift/devs'): writer.write_json(ring['devs']) # Next comes the replica2part2dev table assignments = sum(len(a) for a in ring['replica2part2dev_id']) length = assignments * ring['dev_id_bytes'] with writer.section('swift/replica2part2dev'): for i, part2dev_id in enumerate(ring['replica2part2dev_id']): with network_order_array(part2dev_id): if i == 0: writer.write(struct.pack('!Q', length)) if six.PY2: # Can't just use tofile() because a GzipFile apparently # doesn't count as an 'open file' writer.write(part2dev_id.tostring()) else: part2dev_id.tofile(writer) if format_version not in (0, 1, 2): 'dev_id_bytes': 2,
deleted_lines: from swift.common.ring.utils import tiers_for_dev writer.write(struct.pack('!4sH', b'R1NG', 1)) if format_version not in (0, 1):

commit_message:
Uncap warlock

warlock recently had a 2.0.0 release that added support for jsonschema
4.x [1]. We no longer need to cap this.

[1] https://github.com/bcwaldon/warlock/releases/tag/2.0.0

Change-Id: I43559379bc71c990361af24b5e2543b426ce84da
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Fix TLS*_METHOD for old pyopenssl releases

The TLS_METHOD constant was introduced in pyopenssl 21.0.0 [0], but some
older Octavia branches (from train to victoria) still use older releases
(19.1.0 for victoria) and then don't support it. Switch back to the
previous the SSL methods if the new constanst doesn't exist.

[0] https://github.com/pyca/pyopenssl/commit/5dc698861c91b4aa83b284b282c0e91cdcee49a3

Change-Id: Ib0eeb1136c168fcc32326f4ed8b008fb7f193a30

commit_message:
Add missing oslo_limit options

Glance now depends on the oslo.limit library to support the unified
quota[1], but parameters of the library are still missing from
glance-api.conf.

This change ensures the parameter of the oslo.limit library are
included in glance-api.conf generated by oslo-config-generator.

[1] 06e6542f153a1ba197361f3f8cb0010c7d2d4285

Closes-Bug: #1946100
Change-Id: I56a2a9d8184f50624239b90dd9bef671c195fb90
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/99/812499/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: namespace = oslo.limit

commit_message:
glance-cache-prefetcher: Set up access to multistore backends

... because the command requires access to backend stores to pull image
data.

(cherry picked from commit 6964e627d5b98c2034aea4bebb72cdab7549b6b5)

commit_message:
[Wallaby-only] Fixes for wallaby molecule jobs

Currently CS8 master dlrn builder is stopped
and removed in future. test_deps role uses master
branch to configure repo and since there will be
no master packages for cs8. The jobs will fail.

Switching it to wallaby release fixes the issue.

Currently cs9 molecule config backport patches
are blocked due to job freeze issue
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/848104/3#message-31598572fd80f4000d3b2e9ff4201dd5e30fc20b
as cs9 content provider[1][2] does not run on molecule changes.

Overriding the irrelvant files, fixes the issue.
[1]. https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ci/src/commit/28ea0202e38945f2a2a88f42c6c15ef8b39e27f6/zuul.d/standalone-jobs.yaml#L119
[2]. https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ci/src/commit/28ea0202e38945f2a2a88f42c6c15ef8b39e27f6/zuul.d/standalone-jobs.yaml#L57

Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I7e213de59a6982e13546da7e83b807d30aab8166

commit_message:
broker: Ensure request-id key is present

When an unexpected error is encountered, the broker response sent
back to the requesting application lacks the request-id key so
can't be matched on the client end of the relation to a specific
request.

Ensure that this is set in all situations including unexpected
error.

Change-Id: I327b406a9fbbe1058e934d0029404f56fc6b2a2e
Related-Bug: 1872043

commit_message:
Use Zed python job template

This repository follows the cycle-with-intermediary release model
which provides at least one deliverable per release, so following
the release-specific job template would be more appropriate.

Change-Id: Ie14257ea33a84b9d6cd8c338001aed958d81bedb

commit_message:
Bump minimum python requirement to 3.8

Cinder has already removed support for python 3.6 and now requires
python >= 3.8 . This change updates the testing runtime accordingly.

Because CentOS Stream 8 has only Python 3.6 available, this change
bumps OS version to 9 which has Python 3.9.

Change-Id: Idf16c3ccb6b3fe6800213dc3e28b5113bcf36c4e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinderlib refs/changes/97/841097/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: python_requires = >=3.6 Programming Language :: Python :: 3.6 Programming Language :: Python :: 3.7

sensible values. Previously, the default values set by the kernel were
used, which limited net.netfilter.nf_conntrack_max to 32768. On the
other hand, Octavia sets nf_conntrack_buckets to 125000. A value of
nf_conntrack_max lower than half of that makes no sense.

The new values are calculated using the formula for the default value
in the kernel [1]:

nf_conntrack_expect_max = nf_conntrack_buckets / 256

commit_message:
Set sensible nf_conntrack_max value in amphora

This sets the values of nf_conntrack_max and nf_conntrack_expect_max to
sensible values. Previously, the default values set by the kernel were
used, which limited net.netfilter.nf_conntrack_max to 32768. On the
other hand, Octavia sets nf_conntrack_buckets to 125000. A value of
nf_conntrack_max lower than half of that makes no sense.

The new values are calculated using the formula for the default value
in the kernel [1]:

nf_conntrack_max = nf_conntrack_buckets
nf_conntrack_expect_max = nf_conntrack_buckets / 256

[1]: https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/networking/nf_conntrack-sysctl.rst

Story: 2010050
Task: 45460
Change-Id: Id1dd029995d41e6913a07eeb120c889d71d583eb
(cherry picked from commit 3d3e38afe9f0186f45e9800090afecc3aa434846)
(cherry picked from commit 78603681cce95048b76e2fcfabcdb0b5baf58c51)
(cherry picked from commit 33eaff55fc59c711e9a74dd94f55d84a54f09f56)
(cherry picked from commit d0adca9a34b5d2f36b821478d4e505f6592f222a)
(cherry picked from commit 4ea8953a698205764fcbc9617f441fd32f6a5ce2)
(cherry picked from commit e367cd09478811113d225b6f59a11df5f31c827a)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/octavia refs/changes/44/847544/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- upgrade: - | The fix that updates the Netfilter Conntrack Sysfs variables requires rebuilding the amphora image in order to be effective. fixes: - | Netfilter Conntrack Sysfs variables net.netfilter.nf_conntrack_max and nf_conntrack_expect_max get set to sensible values on the amphora now. Previously, kernel default values were used which were much too low for the configured net.netfilter.nf_conntrack_buckets value. As a result packets could get dropped because the conntrack table got filled too quickly. Note that this affects only UDP and SCTP protocol listeners. Connection tracking is disabled for TCP-based connections on the amphora including HTTP(S).

commit_message:
Set sensible nf_conntrack_max value in amphora

This sets the values of nf_conntrack_max and nf_conntrack_expect_max to
sensible values. Previously, the default values set by the kernel were
used, which limited net.netfilter.nf_conntrack_max to 32768. On the
other hand, Octavia sets nf_conntrack_buckets to 125000. A value of
nf_conntrack_max lower than half of that makes no sense.

The new values are calculated using the formula for the default value
in the kernel [1]:

nf_conntrack_max = nf_conntrack_buckets
nf_conntrack_expect_max = nf_conntrack_buckets / 256

[1]: https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/networking/nf_conntrack-sysctl.rst

Story: 2010050
Task: 45460
Change-Id: Id1dd029995d41e6913a07eeb120c889d71d583eb
(cherry picked from commit 3d3e38afe9f0186f45e9800090afecc3aa434846)
(cherry picked from commit 78603681cce95048b76e2fcfabcdb0b5baf58c51)
(cherry picked from commit 33eaff55fc59c711e9a74dd94f55d84a54f09f56)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/octavia refs/changes/41/847541/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- upgrade: - | The fix that updates the Netfilter Conntrack Sysfs variables requires rebuilding the amphora image in order to be effective. fixes: - | Netfilter Conntrack Sysfs variables net.netfilter.nf_conntrack_max and nf_conntrack_expect_max get set to sensible values on the amphora now. Previously, kernel default values were used which were much too low for the configured net.netfilter.nf_conntrack_buckets value. As a result packets could get dropped because the conntrack table got filled too quickly. Note that this affects only UDP and SCTP protocol listeners. Connection tracking is disabled for TCP-based connections on the amphora including HTTP(S).
